private_information: I observe blocks A, B, C, D, and E and their relative stacking.
I can move one block at a time and only the top block of any stack.
mover1.goal: Help determine the final arrangement of all blocks after the provided action sequence.

private_information: I observe blocks F, G, and H and their relative stacking.
I can move one block at a time and only the top block of any stack.
mover2.goal: Help determine the final arrangement of all blocks after the provided action sequence.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate observations and produce a PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards planner that model the Blocks World task and the provided action sequence, in order to determine the final arrangement of each block.

public_information: Standard Blocks World rules: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
Blocks present: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H.
Initial arrangement: A is on top of D.
Initial arrangement: B is on top of E.
Initial arrangement: C is on top of B.
Initial arrangement: D is on the table.
Initial arrangement: E is on top of A.
Initial arrangement: F is on the table.
Initial arrangement: G is on the table.
Initial arrangement: H is on top of G.

report.system_prompt: You are an observer agent that knows the positions of a subset of blocks in a Blocks World instance and the Blocks World rules. Provide a concise report listing the blocks you observe, their initial relations, and describe stepwise how the action sequence affects the blocks you observe. Do not produce PDDL. Provide only a clear human-readable report that the orchestrator can consume.

You are an observer agent that knows the positions of a subset of blocks in a Blocks World instance and the Blocks World rules. Provide a concise report listing the blocks you observe, their initial relations, and describe stepwise how the action sequence affects the blocks you observe. Do not produce PDDL. Provide only a clear human-readable report that the orchestrator can consume.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems. Integrate the observers' reports and the public information to build a complete Blocks World PDDL domain and a PDDL problem. Target the FastDownwards planner: ensure the PDDL is compatible with FastDownwards conventions and does not use unsupported extensions. Produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that model the initial state and that encode the given action sequence as deterministic actions or as a plan goal so the planner can verify and produce the final arrangement. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep agents' roles distinct if modeling multiple actors. Also include, as a short human-readable comment before the PDDL output, the derived final arrangement of every block (state whether each block is on the table or on top of another block).
pddl.prompt: You will receive two human-readable reports from observer agents that together describe the initial configuration and how each action in the provided sequence affects blocks. Use the public information and the reports to produce: 1) A clear derivation of the final arrangement of each block. 2) A PDDL domain and a PDDL problem tailored for the FastDownwards planner that represent the Blocks World instance and allow verifying or reproducing the final arrangement. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. The inputs you receive are: report_mover1 and report_mover2. The global task is to determine the final positions of blocks A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H after the provided 30 actions and to provide the PDDL domain and problem that reflect this instance.
